title: Jewish Schools
description:
Jewish schools, also known as Jewish day schools or yeshivas, are educational institutions that combine secular academics with Jewish religious education, Hebrew language instruction, and cultural studies.

Key characteristics of Jewish schools:

• Dual curriculum combining general studies with Jewish studies
• Hebrew language instruction at various levels
• Jewish history, traditions, and religious education
• Observance of Jewish holidays and Shabbat
• Connection to Jewish community and Israel
• May follow Orthodox, Conservative, Reform, or community-wide approaches

Jewish schools vary significantly based on their denominational affiliation. Orthodox schools typically have more intensive religious study and stricter observance requirements, while community or Reform schools may offer a broader approach to Jewish identity and practice.

Florida has a significant Jewish school presence, particularly in South Florida communities like Miami-Dade, Broward, and Palm Beach counties.

When considering a Jewish school, ask about their denominational approach, Hebrew language requirements, religious observance expectations, and policies for families at different levels of Jewish practice.
